title: Educational Misdirections: Attending to Levinas’s Call for Ethics as First Principle
abstract: ABSTRACTThis essay examines a shift of significance, movement from faculty to increasing administrative impact. The consequence of this change is not only structural but impacts the very nature of an academic calling and vocation. The university is increasingly a business run by an ever-expanding pool of managers. The lament of Benjamin Ginsberg, in The Fall of the Faculty: The Rise of the All-Administrative University and Why It Matters, provides the background conversation for this essay. Emmanuel Levinas’s framing of ethics as first philosophy offers a response to this historical shift in higher education. The task of this essay is modest and perhaps fundamental; there is no attempt to change this historical moment of higher education. This essay explores Levinas and ethics with a hope of sustaining educational commitments in the midst of an educational era of misdirection.

motivations: The shift from faculty to administrative dominance in universities has altered the nature of academic calling and vocation.
The increasing business-like management of universities threatens the core values and commitments of higher education.
objectives: Examine the implications of the shift towards administrative dominance in universities.
Explore Emmanuel Levinas's concept of ethics as first philosophy as a response to the current state of higher education.
Sustain educational commitments amidst the misdirection in the current era of higher education.
methods: Analyze the work of Benjamin Ginsberg, particularly 'The Fall of the Faculty: The Rise of the All-Administrative University and Why It Matters', to understand the background of the issue.
Apply Levinas's philosophical framework of ethics as first philosophy to the context of higher education.
results: Provide a deeper understanding of the impact of administrative dominance on the nature of higher education.
Offer a philosophical perspective on the importance of ethics in guiding educational commitments and values.
